result.execSummary:
On one or more charges, the deferred prosecution or sentencing agreement(s) on this case were fulfilled, and the charge(s) were dismissed.

The defendant Anthony D Slate was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Anthony D Slate is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Anthony D Slate was found guilty of Theft-Movable Property <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).
  • Anthony D Slate was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Anthony D Slate

records.addlTxt: for Dismissal (State's)
Order for Dismissal (State's)
(Per the retirement of Judge Bernard Bult, this matter has been reassigned to Judge Chad Hendee)
COUNT ONE (State's)

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.
Motion and order for withdrawal of counsel

records.addlTxt:
ADDRESS INFO for Anthony D Slate
Current: 295 S Main Street, Markesan, WI 53946 United States  (Effective: 10-13-2016)
Prior: 295 S Main St, Markesan, WI 53946
Plea Diversion Agreement - for a period of 24 months.

3:01 p.m.  Defendant present in court with Atty John Selsing.  Andrew Christenson for the State of Wisconsin.  DA Christenson recites agreement.  

Court questions defendant.  Court questions Atty Selsing.  Atty Selsing waives prelim.  Defendant concurs.  Court accepts waiver and binds defendant over for trial.  

DA Christenson files Information.  Atty Selsing confirms receipt and waives reading.  Defendant enters a plea of no contest to Counts 1, 3 and 4.  

Court goes over plea questionnaire with the defendant.  Court goes over constitutional rights with the defendant - defendant waives these rights.  Court goes over the elements of each offense.  Court instructs defendant of the maximum penalty.  Court instructs defendant regarding deportation. 

Court accepts plea and finds there is a factual basis to support the plea.   Court orders the judgment of conviction be entered here today on counts 3 and 4.  DA confirms compliance with victim witness rights. Sentencing statement by DA.  Sentencing statement by Atty Selsing.  No statement by the defendant.

DA Christenson requests count 2 be dismissed.  Court so orders.  DA Christenson states there is a 9 day jail credit.  

Court sentences the defendant to:

COUNT 1:  Court orders the judgment of conviction be withheld pending compliance with the Plea Diversion Agreement - 2 years.  

COUNT 3:  Court enters judgment of conviction as of today and withholds sentence for a period of 2 years probation.

COUNT 4:  Court enters judgment of conviction as of today and withholds sentence for a period of 2 years probation  concurrent. 

CONDITIONS OF COUNT 3:

Count 3 -3 months conditional jail sentence,  to commence forthwith and to run concurrent with any sentence defendant may be serving, and with Huber.
-Complete AODA and follow up with any recommended treatment.
-Subject to random UAs, random but a minimum of one time per month.
-Write letter of apology to victim within 30 days, with copy to the Court.
-DNA Sample.
-Mandatory court costs and DNA surcharge.


CONDITIONS OF COUNT 4:

Same conditions as count 3.  

Court grants jail credit of 9 days, not to count against conditional jail time as ordered in count 3.

Court adjourned 3:27 p.m.

Per Kathe - Judge Bult's JA - this matter will be a waiver of prelim, arraignment and plea & sentencing.  Change hearing in computer, but no new notice of hearing needed.
43

By Atty John Selsing
